abstracts.cdata!:
The project assessment is satisfactory,
            with a likely sustainability. While the project contributed
            to increase the agricultural productivity in selected
            rainfed areas, not all instruments foreseen in the
            achievement of project objectives, were used in a balanced
            way, thus having a negative impact in the extent of project
            development impact. Several lessons are drawn from the
            project. The absence of adequate technical assistance (TA)
            for infrastructure outputs failed to support development
            objectives, for although adequate infrastructure may be
            enough to promote expansion of irrigation, and an increase
            in crop yields, it does not induce changes in crop patterns,
            and production. Not only should project design have included
            safeguards against low demand for TA, but elements such as
            macroeconomics, in accord with private financial support,
            should complement on-farm investments, and technical
            assistance. Furthermore, a comprehensive operational
            framework should have been enforced, to ensure coordination
            among components, particularly in light of two implementing
            agencies controlling different components. Project
            experience acknowledges the importance of performance
            indicators, beneficiary participation in project design, and
            assessment of commitments, particularly in meeting
            counterpart funds requirements under macroeconomic instability.

18224917.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Technology diffusion,Administrative and civil service reform
18224917.majtheme: Rural development,Trade and integration,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rainfed Areas Development Project
            will raise agricultural production in selected rainfed
            areas. This will be done through: (a) investing in
            small-scale irrigation and other productive investments; (b)
            transferring both new and existing agricultural technologies
            through private sector extension; (c) reducing costs of soil
            erosion; and (d) strengthening the capacity of the executing
            agency. The project is targeted at small farmers in the ten
            states, chiefly in semiarid and temperate zones, with
            rainfall less than 1,000 mm annually and where moisture
            deficit is the main constraint to productivity. The
            operation will have three components: (a) rural investment;
            (b) agricultural technology transfer; and (c) institutional
            development and training.
